changes.original_text: Unit prices are fixed as per Schedule A for the entire contract period.
changes.proposed_text: Unit prices are fixed as per Schedule A for the entire contract period. Volume-based discounts shall apply as follows: (a) 5% discount for quarterly orders exceeding 10,000 units; (b) 8% discount for quarterly orders exceeding 20,000 units; (c) 12% discount for quarterly orders exceeding 30,000 units.
changes.vendor_feedback: We propose adding volume-based discount tiers for quarterly orders exceeding 10,000 units. This would incentivize bulk ordering and provide cost savings for both parties.
changes.ai_reasoning: Volume-based pricing tiers align with industry best practices for blanket purchase agreements and create win-win incentives. At current consumption estimates (15,000 units/quarter), this generates 5-8% cost savings (Rp 300M-600M annually). The tiered structure encourages consolidated ordering which reduces vendor's administrative costs.

changes.original_text: Standard delivery time shall be 7-10 business days from order placement.
changes.proposed_text: Standard delivery time shall be 7-10 business days from order placement. For critical emergency requirements, Vendor shall provide expedited delivery: (a) 24-hour delivery for orders up to 500 units with 15% premium; (b) 48-hour delivery for orders up to 2,000 units with 12% premium.
changes.vendor_feedback: We suggest including a provision for expedited delivery (24-48 hours) for emergency replacement needs, with an agreed premium charge of 15% for such urgent orders.
changes.ai_reasoning: Expedited delivery provision is critical for operational continuity in power generation facilities. The premium pricing (12-15%) is reasonable and protects against abuse while ensuring availability. Recommend adding requirement for Procurement Manager approval to control costs.

changes.original_text: All air filters shall comply with ISO 9001:2015 quality management standards and pass third-party testing for filtration efficiency.
changes.proposed_text: All air filters shall comply with ISO 9001:2015 standards. Filters for critical equipment (marked 'CRITICAL' in PO) shall additionally meet ISO 14644 Class 7 cleanroom certification with documentation provided per shipment.
changes.vendor_feedback: The ISO 9001:2015 quality standards are clear, but we'd like to add ISO 14644 Class 7 cleanroom certification for filters designated for critical power generation equipment.
changes.ai_reasoning: Enhanced certification for critical applications is prudent but adds cost and complexity. Recommend limiting to equipment explicitly marked as critical to balance quality assurance with cost efficiency. Vendor capability confirmed via certification review.

changes.original_text: Payment shall be made within 60 calendar days from invoice date via bank transfer.
changes.proposed_text: Payment within 60 days via bank transfer. Early payment discounts available: (a) 2% discount for payment within 15 days; (b) 1% discount for payment within 30 days. Discounts calculated on net invoice amount before taxes.
changes.vendor_feedback: The 60-day payment term is longer than our standard 30-day terms. We request consideration for either 45-day payment terms or early payment discount of 2% for payments within 15 days.
changes.ai_reasoning: Early payment discount structure addresses vendor concerns while maintaining standard 60-day terms. The 2%/1% discount tiers provide flexibility and potential cost savings (up to Rp 400M annually if consistently using 15-day option). Finance approval required for cash flow impact assessment.

changes.original_text: Payment shall be made within 30 days from invoice date
changes.proposed_text: Payment shall be made within 45 days from invoice date
changes.vendor_feedback: Request extension due to cash flow management and typical industry practice of 45-60 days. Our supply chain requires longer payment cycles to optimize working capital.
changes.ai_reasoning: The vendor's request for 45-day payment terms is reasonable and aligns with industry standards for equipment suppliers. This change reduces financial risk for the vendor while remaining within acceptable corporate payment policies (standard 30-60 days). Recommend approval with no material impact on contract value.

changes.original_text: All equipment shall be delivered within 90 days of purchase order
changes.proposed_text: All equipment shall be delivered within 120 days of purchase order, with interim delivery milestones at 60 days (40%), 90 days (35%), and 120 days (25%)
changes.vendor_feedback: Current global supply chain constraints make 90-day delivery unrealistic. Request 120-day timeline with phased deliveries to ensure quality control and proper logistics coordination. This also allows for better production scheduling.
changes.ai_reasoning: Extended delivery timeline is justified given current supply chain realities. The proposed milestone-based approach (60-90-120 days) actually provides better visibility and risk management. However, recommend adding penalty clauses for missed milestones to maintain vendor accountability.
conditions: Add 1% penalty per week for missed milestones (max 5%)
Require weekly progress reports
Include force majeure exemptions only for documented events

changes.original_text: Supplier warrants equipment for 24 months from final acceptance
changes.proposed_text: Supplier warrants equipment for 18 months from final acceptance, with option to purchase extended warranty
changes.vendor_feedback: 24-month warranty significantly increases our reserve costs. Industry standard for this equipment type is 12-18 months. We can offer extended warranty as paid option.
changes.ai_reasoning: Reduction from 24 to 18 months represents material change in risk allocation. Industry research shows 18 months is acceptable but below best practice. Recommendation: Counter-propose 21 months standard warranty, or require extended warranty at no additional cost as contract concession.
changes.financial_impact: Increased maintenance cost: Rp 75M over equipment life
alternative_proposals: Require extended warranty (24 months total) at no cost

changes.original_text: Supplier liability shall not exceed the total contract value
changes.proposed_text: Supplier liability shall not exceed 50% of the total contract value, except for cases of willful misconduct or fraud
changes.vendor_feedback: Request liability cap at 50% of contract value to align with our insurance coverage and industry standards. Unlimited liability exposure is not commercially viable for equipment suppliers.
changes.ai_reasoning: 50% liability cap is below industry standard for equipment of this value and criticality. Given the Rp 2.45B contract value and potential operational impact, recommend maintaining full contract value liability cap. The exception for willful misconduct is reasonable and should be retained.
changes.counter_proposal: Maintain 100% liability cap with three-tier structure: (1) Direct damages: 100% (2) Consequential damages: 50% (3) Willful misconduct: Unlimited

changes.original_text: Supplier shall provide performance bond of 10% of contract value
changes.proposed_text: Supplier shall provide performance bond of 5% of contract value
changes.vendor_feedback: 10% performance bond ties up significant working capital. Industry standard is 5% for established suppliers with proven track record. Our company has 20+ years operating history and strong financial standing.
changes.ai_reasoning: Vendor has strong credit rating and established track record. 5% performance bond is acceptable for low-risk vendors per corporate policy. However, recommend maintaining 10% for first milestone, reducing to 5% after successful 60-day delivery milestone as performance incentive.
conditions: Maintain 10% bond through first delivery milestone
Reduce to 5% after successful 60-day milestone delivery
Revert to 10% if any milestone missed by >2 weeks

changes.original_text: Force majeure events include natural disasters, war, government action
changes.proposed_text: Force majeure events include natural disasters, war, government action, pandemic, supply chain disruptions, and labor disputes beyond supplier's reasonable control
changes.vendor_feedback: Request explicit inclusion of pandemic and supply chain disruptions as force majeure given recent global events. Also need protection for labor disputes at our suppliers/subcontractors.
changes.ai_reasoning: Pandemic and documented supply chain disruptions are reasonable force majeure additions post-COVID. However, 'labor disputes' is overly broad and could be abused. Recommend accepting pandemic and supply chain disruptions (with documentation requirement), but limiting labor disputes to only those affecting multiple suppliers industry-wide.
conditions: Accept pandemic and supply chain disruptions with 48-hour notification requirement
Limit labor disputes to industry-wide events only
Require documentation and mitigation plan within 7 days
Exclude labor disputes caused by supplier's employment practices

changes.original_text: All IP rights in custom modifications vest in Buyer
changes.proposed_text: IP rights in custom modifications vest in Buyer for internal use only. Supplier retains rights to underlying technology and may use learnings for other clients (subject to confidentiality)
changes.vendor_feedback: Need to clarify that while customer gets IP for custom work, we retain our base technology and can apply learnings to improve our products for other customers. This is standard in equipment supply contracts.
changes.ai_reasoning: Clarification is reasonable and aligns with industry practice. Buyer retains custom modification IP for internal use while supplier protects base technology. This is mutually beneficial and encourages innovation. Recommend approval with explicit confidentiality requirements.

changes.original_text: Buyer may inspect equipment upon delivery
changes.proposed_text: Buyer may inspect equipment upon delivery. Buyer shall complete inspection within 14 days. Equipment deemed accepted if no written objection within 14 days.
changes.vendor_feedback: Need defined inspection timeline to avoid indefinite acceptance delays. 14-day inspection with deemed acceptance is standard practice and fair to both parties.
changes.ai_reasoning: 14-day inspection period with deemed acceptance is commercially reasonable. However, recommend adding: (1) Exception for latent defects discovered within warranty period (2) Requirement for supplier to provide inspection support (3) Stop-clock provisions for complex testing requiring external expertise.
conditions: Add exception: Latent defects discoverable within warranty period
Require supplier technical support during inspection
Allow inspection period extension for complex testing (max 30 days total)
Define clear acceptance criteria checklist

changes.original_text: Contract price is fixed for entire contract duration
changes.proposed_text: Contract price is fixed for first 12 months. Price may be adjusted after 12 months based on published PPI (Producer Price Index) for industrial equipment, capped at 5% annually
changes.vendor_feedback: In current inflationary environment, we need some price protection for multi-year contract. Request modest inflation adjustment after first year, capped at 5% and tied to official PPI index.
changes.ai_reasoning: Price escalation request is reasonable for long-term contract given inflation. PPI-based adjustment is objective and verifiable. 5% cap is acceptable. However, recommend: (1) First adjustment only after 18 months (not 12) (2) Require 90-day advance notice (3) Include de-escalation clause if PPI decreases.
conditions: First adjustment only after 18 months (not 12)
Require 90-day written notice before any adjustment
Include de-escalation clause if PPI decreases
Cap cumulative increases at 15% over contract life
Provide opt-out right if increase exceeds 7% in any year

changes.original_text: Either party may terminate for convenience with 60 days notice
changes.proposed_text: Buyer may terminate for convenience with 60 days notice. Supplier may terminate only for material breach with 90 days cure period.
changes.vendor_feedback: As equipment supplier with significant upfront investment, we need protection against arbitrary cancellation. Request mutual termination for cause only, or if buyer retains convenience termination, require payment for work-in-progress and reasonable profit margin.
changes.ai_reasoning: Asymmetric termination rights are appropriate given buyer's position. However, vendor's concern about upfront investment is valid. Recommend maintaining buyer's convenience termination right but adding fair compensation: (1) Payment for completed work (2) Reimbursement of non-cancellable commitments (3) 10% restocking fee for materials purchased. This balances buyer flexibility with vendor protection.
changes.financial_impact: Termination cost: Variable based on timing
conditions: Add termination compensation clause
Payment for all completed work at contract rates
Reimbursement of non-cancellable commitments with documentation
10% restocking fee for materials purchased for this project
No compensation for lost profit on uncompleted work

changes.proposed_text: Supplier shall maintain $2M liability insurance, with option to increase to $5M for specific high-risk phases
changes.vendor_feedback: Maintaining $5M coverage year-round is cost-prohibitive. Our standard coverage is $2M which is adequate for most activities. Can increase to $5M during installation and commissioning phases when risk is higher.
changes.ai_reasoning: Insurance requirement should match risk profile. $2M may be insufficient for Rp 2.45B contract. Recommend: (1) Maintain $3M minimum coverage at all times (2) Increase to $5M during delivery, installation, and first 90 days of operation (3) Require buyer to be named as additional insured (4) Provide certificates of insurance quarterly.
changes.counter_proposal: $3M minimum year-round, $5M during high-risk phases (delivery, installation, commissioning, first 90 days operation). Buyer named as additional insured. Quarterly certificate of insurance required.

changes.original_text: Disputes shall be resolved by arbitration in Jakarta under Indonesian law
changes.proposed_text: Disputes shall first be escalated to senior management for 30-day resolution attempt. If unresolved, mediation for 30 days. If still unresolved, arbitration in Jakarta under Indonesian law.
changes.vendor_feedback: Request multi-tier dispute resolution to preserve business relationship and avoid costly arbitration for minor issues. Senior management escalation and mediation often resolve disputes efficiently.
changes.ai_reasoning: Multi-tier dispute resolution is best practice and cost-effective. Escalation and mediation attempts before arbitration are prudent and often resolve issues without legal proceedings. This change reduces costs for both parties and preserves relationship. Strongly recommend approval.
changes.financial_impact: Potential savings: Rp 100-500M in arbitration costs
